context.text: There, the question was, do admiralty claims arise under Federal law under 1331, and Justice Frankfurter, writing for the Court, said no, and the main reason he gave was that if they did, we would have to look at each admiralty claim and say, does this arise under State law or under Federal law, what's the Governing law, and he said, that type of analysis is inappropriate at the jurisdictional stage, and it's just as inappropriate today as it was in 1959.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --But your position remains that if you lose on your limitation claim there's no more admiralty jurisdiction, there's no more maritime law governing this case.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, the number of areas in which State law apply are many.

context.text: The Court listed some of them in Romero, and it dealt with another one just last term in American Dredging.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's an admiralty case in State court under the savings to suitors clause, but the question was, what law applies on forum non conveniens, State or Federal, and the difficult analysis in that case that gave rise to four different opinions is as good a reason not to adopt a choice-of-law rule for jurisdiction as can be imagined.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's the reason Justice Frankfurter gave in Romero.

context.text: In this case, the police officer found the plaintiff banging his head against the wall, and by the time the arrest had been completed and he'd been hauled off to jail, he was found to have suffered from broken ribs and other physical injuries that are not consistent with banging the head against the wall.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: Ordinarily, the courts of appeals consider on appeal of a question which is legitimately before them, and the question here can always be raised whether what the defendant did violated clearly established law.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld

context.text: Mr. Rothfeld, I still think that the clearly established law is coming into this case when it really doesn't fit.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.text: The opinion of the Court in number 93-1121 Plaut v. Spendthrift Farm, Inc. will be announced by Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case is here on petition for certiorari to the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In a civil action brought 1987, petitioners alleged that in 1983 and 1984 respondents had committed fraud and deceit in the sale of stock in violation of Federal Securities Laws.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We granted certiorari in the present case to consider the question again with full Court.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We hold today that §27A (b) violates the constitution separation of powers because it requires Federal Courts to reopen final judgments entered before its enactment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Article III of the constitution, provides that the judicial power of the United States shall be vested in one Supreme Court and in such Inferior Courts as the Congress may from time-to-time ordain and establish.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This article establishes a judicial department with as Chief Justice Marshall said in Marbury v. Madison, “the province and duty to say what the law is in particular cases and controversies” he Framers crafted this charter with an expressed understanding that it gives the Federal Judiciary the power, not merely to rule on cases, but conclusively to decide them, subject to review only by Superior Courts in the Article III hierarchy.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: History makes clear that the right against which the constitution doctrine of separation of powers was meant to protect was not merely legislative reversal of judicial judgments but also legislative setting aside of judicial judgments.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In the 17th and 18th centuries colonial assemblies and legislatures often vacated final judgments and the populism that swept the country during the revolution increased the frequency of that practice.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Apart from §27A (b) we know of no instance in which Congress has attempted to set aside the final judgment of an Article III Court by retroactive legislation.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Congresses prolonged reticence would be amazing, if such interference were not understood to be constitutionally proscribed by the constitutions separation of powers.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment; Justice Stevens has filed the dissenting opinion in which Justice Ginsberg joins.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And he also says that the factors don't have any necessary... you don't know which one is the heaviest and how to weigh them, but I don't know why, even within the Colorado River formulation, one couldn't say that a district judge has some discretion to decide whether, given the case going forward in two different court systems, which one is a better forum for adjudicating the merits.

context.speaker: Michael A. Orlando
context.text: --Part of the problem with that approach, Your Honor, is that if this Court does not give some guidance to the lower courts as to which factors should or should not be looked at by the district court, then in essence the Court is granting unfettered discretion, and what is or may happen is the district court may simply look at his docket and say, my docket is overcrowded with criminal cases--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Is that a sufficient factor?

context.speaker: Michael A. Orlando
context.text: --If that's the only factor, then I would say no, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Michael A. Orlando
context.text: Although it is a fairly compelling factor in and of itself, if the Court didn't look at some of the other reasons why the case might properly be in Federal court, then it would be our contention that again, that would be basically unfettered discretion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Orlando, you answered Justice O'Connor that that is indeed the issue here, whether we should use as a jurisdictional issue what we have said to be the basis for a merits determination under declaratory judgment actions, but is that really the issue?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do we know that the dismissal in the district court here was a jurisdictional dismissal?

context.speaker: Michael A. Orlando
context.text: Yes, we do, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If it's reinstituted there may be a statute of limitations question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Maybe that was the logic behind the stay.

context.speaker: Werner A. Powers
context.text: I think so, but I'm not so sure you have a statute of limitations issue with a declaratory judgment action in this case, but that would be... that is typically one of the reasons for staying instead of dismissing, is to avoid any kind of statute of limitations bar.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: How did the... Justice Stevens and I were just speculating, how does a stay get to be appealable as a final order?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, suppose he hadn't announced a stay, just put it at the bottom of his stack of cases, just didn't get to it for several years?

context.speaker: Werner A. Powers
context.text: If memory serves, and I always hate to pull a case out of the top of my head, but doesn't the Landis case speak to a situation where a trial court abuses its discretion by manipulating its docket in such way as to, in essence, never reach judgment on a case?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinions of the court in two cases will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The first case is number 94-562, Wilton versus Seven Falls Company and this case comes here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The petitioners are various insurance underwriters.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We believe that's more consistent with the statute to vest district courts with the discretion in the first instance because facts bearing on the fitness of the case for resolution are peculiarly within their knowledge and grasp.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Accordingly, we hold a proper measure of review is the abusive discretion standard. Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The opinion is unanimous.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. DuMont, we'll hear from you.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: This Court's cases have always permitted consideration at sentencing of conduct that is not part of the offense of conviction, whether or not that conduct has led to other convictions, precisely because the sentence imposed at any given proceeding constitutes punishment only for the offense that is actually before the court in that proceeding.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Will you tell us, in response to the question Justice O'Connor asked of the petitioner's counsel, if in your view there is no prematurity here, that we have the issue squarely before us, and subsidiary to that, why are you prosecuting this person a second time if you don't intend to enhance his punishment?

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: In response to the first question, we think that, although there is some slight doubt on it, we think the issues are squarely presented.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: The only doubt would arise if you could not reach the double jeopardy question until the sentencing stage of the second trial.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: We chose to go ahead and prosecute that case, which seems to me the right answer when we have people in jail.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: We did not prosecute the cocaine conspiracy because his coconspirator was at large for most of this period, and the investigation was not yet completed.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: Once we picked up the coconspirator, we promptly charged the second conspiracy, the cocaine conspiracy, and proceeded to try that.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Then I didn't understand the answer to Justice O'Connor's question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If in the first trial the cocaine is simply relevant conduct, how could it count as two strikes?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Wouldn't you have to bring the second prosecution to make it a second strike?

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: That has always been--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No, what--

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: --part of the fabric of sentencing law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --What the problem, I think, was... I mean, I don't want to put words in other people's mouths, but I thought that Justice Stevens was driving at the different problem of a later prosecution, and what you are prosecuting this person for is the thing for which he was punished previously, required by law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's not the recidivism statute at all.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In a recidivism statute you're punishing the person for what he did later, and the amount of the punishment is a function of what happened before.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That is, a defendant in that situation is only punished for the offenses of which he was convicted.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In a case decided in 1959 called Williams against Oklahoma, we specifically rejected the claim that the double jeopardy principles bar a later prosecution or punishment for criminal activity where that activity has been considered at sentencing for a separate crime.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now the reason that this case and other cases applies of equal force here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Kennedy and I have joined all but Part III of Justice O'Connors opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Stevens has joined only Part III.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion.
